Executive Summary City of Chickasha WWTP

The City of Chickasha WWTP has prepared and implemented a risk management program in accordance with the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions of 40 CFR Part 68 to prevent Chlorine exposure to Chickasha operators and members of the community as well as the environment.  This Risk Management Plan (RMP) encompasses all the elements of the Risk Management Program.  Accidental release prevention, emergency response policies at the Chickasha WWTP emphasize safety, training, and maintenance.

The Chickasha WWTP is located in Chickasha, Oklahoma.  Chlorine is used to disinfect waste water and Sulfur Dioxide is used to remove Chlorine prior to discharge in the Washita River.  The Chickasha Facility treats an average of 2.5 million gallon per day and is designed to treat 6 MGD.  The facility will have the maximum of 8000 pounds of chlorine and 7200 pounds of Sulfur Dioxide on site at any one time.  The chlorine is stored in 1-ton cylinders, 2 in process and 2 in standby.  Sulfur Dioxide is stored in 1-ton cylinders and 150 pound cylinders.  Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide is drawn from the cylinders in a gaseous state.

The Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide cylinders and feed system are checked at least twice daily for leaks and feed rates.  The preventative maintenance program has numberous operator and maintenance checks to ensure full and proper operation.

A worst-case scenario has been estimated, per EPA guidance, to provide the greatest distance in any direction to the established toxic endpoint.  The worst-case release quantitiy established by the regulations, is the greatest amount of chlorine held in a single cylinder.  Chickasha WWTP worst-case is 1-ton cylinder (2000 pounds).  In accordance with 40 CFR section 68.25, chlorine gas released at a rate of 200 pounds per minute with a ten (10) minute release.

No administrative controls or active mitigation measures were included for the worst-case release scenario.  Tables from the EP

A and Chemical Emergency Preparedness and Prevention Office (CEPPO) Risk Management Program Guidance for Waste Water Treatment Plants, were used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case release scenario, a distance of 1.3 miles.

The five year accident history was evaluated to determine a likely alternative release scenario.  No release was recorded for the previous five years.

Severn Trent has developed accidental release repsonse and prevention programs in the form of Risk Management Plans, Emergency Action Plans, training with local ememrgency responders, Operator training, Operator inspection of the Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide systems, and preventative maintenance programs.

Severn Trent will conduct training with local ememrgency responders more frequently.  Operators will be trained and drills conducted as per the facility RMP.
